comment._content: Another LOC photo of her, not from the Bain collection, is titled "Mrs. Bartlett Boder, one of first American women to drive an ambulance in European War, full-length portrait, standing, facing left' www.loc.gov/pictures/item/91794415/ Interviews with her appeared in several newspapers. She had been driving a three ton truck and ambulances in France for the British for 8 months when she arrived in New York on the liner St. Louis on September 12, 1915 when this photo was likely taken. She was 26, and from Whitestone, Long Island. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00F15FA385B17738... news.google.com/newspapers?id=UBJNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HUgDA... One source says she was a singer, performing under the name Mary Carter. www.ourstory.info/library/2-ww1/Hervier/volontaires1.html

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: She's mentioned in Ryan Corbett Bell, The Ambulance: A History (McFarland 2009), p. 122: "One of the first American women to go overseas in this capacity was the singer Mary Carter, who told a New York Times reporter in 1915 that she had volunteered with the Allies in January. In an article appearing September 13 of that year, the 26 year old told how she had been originally assigned to drive a three-ton truck for the British Transport Service but had later been given charge of an ambulance...'the first time I started it I knocked down a soldier because the machine jumped so quickly, and I had become accustomed to the slow movement of the three-ton truck.'...The intrepid Times reporter caught up with her as she steamed into New York to prove to her family in Long Island that, despite the efforts of the Hun zeppelins, she still lived, but she assured the reading public that she would be returning to the front, and her ambulance, after a few weeks of rest." And there's a caption mentioning her on p. 123: "Twelve years after Emily Dunning started her career as an ambulance surgeon, Mary Carter (Mrs. Bartlett Boder) became one of the first American women to drive an ambulance during World War I, chauffeuring a British ambulance truck at the front lines in 1915." books.google.com/books?id=-YtlthqHmHsC&lpg=PA123&... Looks like she divorced Bartlett Boder in March 1917; in August 1918 she married again, to John Williamson Lee (Harvard 1904). Their daughter Mary Lee died in infancy. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn90061457/1917-03-31/ed-... books.google.com/books?id=foUfAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA87&o... www.bklyn-genealogy-info.com/Cemetery/GW3.html A "Mary Carter Lee" was the sister of Frank Carter (c1888-1920), a popular Broadway performer, and was mentioned in an article about a memorial after his untimely death--seems like it could be the same woman. www.ibdb.com/person.php/person.php?id=34748 news.google.com/newspapers?id=MpQtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5ZcFA...

comment._content: Excellent sleuthing. I see she was in the Social Register, living at a tony Manhattan address, into the 50's. Her husband died suddenly of heart disease at age 48 in 1931. He was the grandson of New York City mayor (1833-34) and the son of a leading leather merchant, Charles Lee. His real estate firm was called Lee & Carter. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50A10FB345E1B72...
